title.text: Portable Features for Classifying Emotional Text

abstractContent.text: Are word-level affect lexicons useful in detecting emotions at sentence level?
Some prior research finds no gain over and above what is obtained with ngram features-arguably the most widely used features in text classification.
Here, we experiment with two very different emotion lexicons and show that even in supervised settings, an affect lexicon can provide significant gains.
We further show that while ngram features tend to be accurate, they are often unsuitable for use in new domains.
On the other hand, affect lexicon features tend to generalize and produce better results than ngrams when applied to anew domain.

introductionContent.text: Automatically identifying emotions expressed in text has a number of applications, including tracking customer satisfaction (, determining popularity of politicians and government policies (), depression detection (, affect-based search, and improving human-computer interaction).

entities.text: Automatically identifying emotions expressed in text

introductionContent.text: Supervised methods for classifying emotions expressed in a sentence tend to perform better than unsupervised ones.

entities.text: classifying emotions expressed in a sentence

introductionContent.text: They use features such as unigrams and bigrams.
For example, a system can learn that the word excruciating tends to occur in sentences labeled with sadness, and use this word as a feature in classifying new sentences.
Approaches that do not rely on supervised training with sentence-level annotations often use affect lexicons.
An affect lexicon, in its simplest form, is a list of words and associated emotions and sentiments.
For example, the word excruciating maybe associated with the emotions of sadness and fear.
Note that such lexicons are at best indicators of probable emotions, and that in any given sentence, the full context may suggest that a completely different emotion is being expressed.

Therefore, it is unclear how useful such word-level emotion lexicons are for detecting emotions and meanings expressed in sentences, especially since supervised systems relying on tens of thousands of unigrams and bigrams can produce results that are hard to surpass.

entities.text: detecting emotions and meanings expressed in sentences

introductionContent.text: For example, it is possible that classifiers can learn from unigram features alone that excruciating is associated with sadness and fear.
In this paper, we investigate whether wordemotion association lexicons can provide gains in addition to those already provided by ngram features.
We conduct experiments with different affect lexicons and determine their usefulness in this extrinsic task.
We also conduct experiments to determine how portable the ngram features and the emotion lexicon features are to anew domain.
